title: Homo Naledi Jaw from Rising Star Cave

description.text: You would have to have been living in a cave for the last couple of weeks to have not heard of the amazing discoveries made in South Africa's Rising Star cave. More than 1500 specimens representing parts of at least 15 skeletons have been excavated so far. The skeletons are thought to be the first representatives of a new species, Homo naledi. Scientists from the University of the Witwatersrand's Evolutionary Studies Institute scanned a portion of the artifacts with a Next Engine desktop scanner and made many of their models available at http://morphosource.org/. Many of the models would only be of interest to someone in that field, but there are a couple of more spectacular crowd pleasing specimens as well. I chose U.W. 101-1261, a mandible or lower jaw and U.W. 101-127, a partial maxilla, or upper jaw, which goes with it. The models needed a little clean up to make them printable. I recommend printing them at about a 45 degree angle (see picture) on full support and a raft, if necessary. This orientation minimizes top surface topo artifacts and support scarring. We talked about this technique and a whole lot more on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, or Stitcher radio learn more at http://www.threedprintingtoday.com/ I printed copies for my kid's schools, and so can you.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

30%

Notes: Print at 45 degree angle to the build plate on full support to avoid layer line artifacts and support scarring.
The jaw as printed on support

comments.text: Heard about part on your show. printed it at angle like suggested, support marks practically nonexistant, and where they exist they are very irregular, so they dont stand out. Very nice print. Took it to office to show resident paleo-nerd, excellent reaction received. I use ancient fossil explanation to explain why i have a human jaw bone sitting in the cubicle, so its a great conversation starter. And it is just fun to handle, the teeth feel so real, and are in such good shape. Also the cut in the jaw one one side exposes the roots of a tooth. Lots of great detail to see on this piece.

title: Recorder for #MAKEITLOUD
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I originally wanted this recorder to be plain and simple, but remembering how much my fingers hurt as a kid after hours of playing on the recorder, I decided to add grooves around the holes because it adds a more ergonomic feel to the recorder. The hand holds on the sides also give the user somewhere to easily hold the recorder while not covering any holes. We all know your lips can get tired if they are the only thing holding your recorder. This thing was made with TinkerCAD.
I am new to modeling and just wanted to enter a challenge. So any feedback will be appreciated.
If you print this, please message me so I can see how it turns out.

title: Gebhardt 3D  - up and working ...and almost finished!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
(working title "Daedalus 3D") One day this might be a my big and mighty 3D Printer :) I chose the same concept as ultimater and scaled it a bit up. This can be done without laser cutter, but easily with jigsaw. first i decided to build a reprap mendel. but printing all the parts and assemble the 500screws also take a lot of time. and i don't like the design of reprap. it doesent look very aesthetic in my optinion. so i considered to make my own design i could made within a few hours that is stable and covers the power supply boards and cables. the wooden pieces were precut by the local store. the rest was done with a jigsaw and a portable screwdriver. for material i chose beech multiplex and i broght them precut in 8 pieces: 2x 3246 (sides)
1x 4644 (back)
3x 3044 (bottom mittle and top)
1x 944 (front-top)
1x 12*44 (front-bottom)

about 1 sqm material, beech multiplex (about 25eur)

the parts for the building surface are made of waste from the cut-outs of the other parts. the whole box was build in 3 hours. i dont know the effective build volume yet, but it could be up to 30l20w20h cm i think. btw this was another reason for designing my own case: making bigger things. tomorrow i will get the rods :) electornics: gen7 with opto endstops / pololu stepper drivers/ usb breakout board / nema 17 steppers
Not finished yet.

comments.text: I disagree, I think having a design made for production by hand is great. I live in an area with a population of a couple of million people and I do not have access to a CNC router or Laser that is not a commercial venture with high prices. But with a full size printable template and some glue I can have ten exact copies of this for the price of a jigsaw blade. And from personal experience I can say that a skilled builder can build a highly precise machine with hand tools.

This is a 3D printed flashlight that I created and printed myself. It's a pretty easy print and shouldn't need any support material. I've included two options, printing in 3 parts and screwing together, or printing as one piece. I would recommend trying to one piece option as it frees up some room for wires to occupy. If anyone creates one I'd love to see it! YouTube video showing my design process, printing and assembly:
https://youtu.be/ghMt4RsVrP8 Electronics Parts You'll Need:
Wire: http://www.adafruit.com/products/1970 Rocker Switch: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/8837 Potentiometers (x3): http://www.adafruit.com/products/1789
(don't forget to add the knob toppers) RGB LEDs (diffused): https://www.sparkfun.com/products/10818 OR RGB LEDs (clear): https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9853 Round Protoboard: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/8810

I designed this using Tinkercad. I just took some measurements of things I knew I wanted inside of it using a small caliper I have. Then I tried to design the flashlight around those. You can see me doing this in the linked video. If you have any questions, post in the comments and I'll do my best to answer.

This is a clip for attaching wiper blades to the wiper arm of an L322 Range Rover. I believe it will work on all models 2003-2012.
The L322 uses what they refer to as "side arm" attachment for its wiper blades. When you buy replacement wiper blades, no plastic clip comes in the box, so if you break the the one on the car whilst trying to get it off (like I did (twice)), you're stuffed. 
This replacement clip is designed to bolt permanently to the end of the wiper arm, and converts it into standard attachment. You can then just push the clip onto the cross bar in the centre of the wiper blade in the way that you are used to, with a satisfying click. This clip also eliminated the sloppiness evident in the original clip, meaning my wipers are no longer noisy.
See instructions. OpenSCAD source attached.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 or less

Infill:

Solid

Clear holes and remove small amount of support after print. You want a tight fit with the M6 and M4 bolts to avoid introducing sloppiness, so don't drill out unnecessarily large. Use 4mm and 6mm bits.
The slot that snaps down onto the wiper blade arm is meant to be marginally narrower than 3mm, and then turn into a 3mm hole at the end. This is to give you that nice snap into position and prevent the clip lifting off the blade. After printing the end section probably won't be a good 3mm hole, so also run a 3mm drill through it (across the clip).

title: Simple Box with acrylic sheet bottom/top

description.text:
This simple box allows a piece of acrylic plastic (also called Perspex) to be used at the top or bottom.
The trick is to insert an "@pause" command into the GCODE just before the later corresponding to the later above the sheet.
My PLA print bonded well to the acrylic and the small inset holds the plate firmly.  
Edit the top of the scad file to contain the correct dimensions of the plastic plate.

title: Fisher Carriage and effector, easy adjust

description.text:
This is a modified version of the fisher carriage and effector to replace carraiges and the acrylic effector parts of the original kit and makes it easier to accurately adjust the positions of the balls.
These parts should also give more positive location of the screws that hold the balls in place.
One area of concern I have with this design is the potential for the screws to come loose, particularly the nuts at the ends of the M3 screws and it may prove necessary to further modify this design to replace them with Nylocks and use  longer screws.

Additional parts required 12 x M3x20 grub screws 12 x M3 Washers 12 x M3 nuts 12 x M3 Nylock nuts (can use the existing ones) You will also need a good pair of calipers to measure accurately All other parts required are standard to the FIsher kit, however I do strongly recommend that you replace the acrylic arms with carbon or printed arms http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?409,553699 http://forums.reprap.org/read.php?409,553622 Build Instructions The build process can be very time consuming and takes a degree of patience. The object is to assemble the parts so that each pair of balls is exactly 50mm between centres (56mm across balls), and for each pair of balls to be central to the assembly. To start the assembly insert the nuts into the slots and screw the grub screws in so they just go through the nuts place a washer over each grub screw, screw on a Nylock nut and tighten the assembly, by putting an Allen key in the grub screw and tighten the Nylock nut with a spanner. Next screw the balls onto the first pair of screws and write down the following three measurements. 1) Across both balls 2) From the left ball to the right washer 3) From the right ball to the left washer Once you have your three measurements you need to adjust the screws so that the measurements across the balls is 56mm and the other two dimensions are equal. TIP, 1 rotation of the screw is equal to 0.5mm, before loosening off the nylock nut put the allen key in the socket and note the position, then loosen the nut and wind the key in or out counting the turns and fractions of each turn, then tighten the nut holding the key in position. After adjusting the screws put the balls back on and remeasure, as you get closer to your goal increase the tightness of the Nylock nut until its as tight as possible without breaking the plastic. For final assembly use Loctite on the balls. Repeat this process for each pair of balls on the effector and carriage.

This frame was created so that I would have a more durable quad-copter than I do with the stock Hubsan H107L frame. However, I also wanted a faster quad-copter. This frame accommodates that because it supports 8.5mm motors like those from the H107C. These motors were meant to be able to take more weight so with the same weight the quad will zip through the air! There is no place to mount the LEDs because I plan to remove them to conserve battery. You will still have 2 surface mount blue LEDs on the front.
The piece on the bottom can be secured to the main frame with nylon bolts. The holes are 3mm wide. There are wire guides on the bottom to help keep it looking nice and tidy! Pictures coming soon!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: I printed this with Shapeways because of now I do not own a 3d printer(thats why I hope to win:)) I used the settings Strong and Flexible with an orange polish. That is about all I can say!

I used the free online 3d design tool called Tinkercad. With this tool you modify basic shapes in order to make what you want. I started out with two rectangles and made them perpendicular to each other. I just went on from there! Fresh off the printer!

I am still continuing to improve my "snakeline" programming approach which I first used for the plastic springs of the flexing battery holders and then for the treble clef. In the meantime, I have enhanced this technique to use OpenScad's child mechanism, so this is one more project trying out this technique in practice... When my daughter, who is teaching German to refugees, saw me doing some test prints with letters based on the snakeline approach, she thought that such letters would be very useful to her teaching, but she would need them to be magnetic, so that they would stick on the white board. Thus, I added conical magnet frames at the rear of the letters, which could be redrilled after printing with a 3mm drill bit, and cylindrical 3x3mm neodymium magnets could be pressed into the holes. This project contains STL objects for capital letters (A-Z), numbers(0-9) and some special characters (@#$%^&*+-!?.,)which are about 10cm high and up to 6cm wide. The fully parametrized SCAD source files are also included snakeline.scad contains the snakeline library and sletters.scad contains the character definitions. Update 2015-10-10: I have now also uploaded the STL files for the lower case characters a-z.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes: I printed these objects from 3mm ABS on my DIY box-frame Prusa i3, using a 0.40mm nozzle with 0.25mm layer height and 0.56mm extrusion width. I always print on a clear mirror without Kapton tape, but thoroughly cleaned with acetone and double concentrated lemon juice.

After printing, I redrilled each conical hole at the rear of the letter with a 3mm drill to about 4mm depth.  I then removed any drill brim and pushed a cylindrical 3x3mm neodymium magnet into the hole.  I did this by taping a bigger magnet onto the working table, putting a 3x3mm magnet on top of it an pressing the letter down on it, using a rubber mallet to make it go in it all the way.  Note that it is important for the magnets to sit firmly in the hole, so that it cannot fall out or be pulled out, even with a very strong magnet.  This prevents magnets from being lost, but even more importantly, it makes sure that no loose magnets will get swallowed by small children - which is very dangerous! 
There is no need to fill all holes with magnets.  Using 2 or 3 magnets for each letter is quite enough, using more make it just more difficult to move or remove the object from the magnetic surface.

I have some sheet-rock to hang and I always have trouble locating the electrical boxes after I have put the sheet-rock over the top of it. I thought that this target system would be an easier way of locating the electrical boxes once the sheet rock is placed over them.
It consists of a magnetic target designed to fit inside the electrical box and a magnetic face-plate that aligns with it through the sheet-rock. The face-plate is sized to the opening that is needed to be cut - making it easy to accurately cut the opening.

The OpenSCAD file is written to be parametric and easy to adapt to different electrical boxes or magnets. All of the important parameters are listed at the top of the file. Care may be needed if the magnets get too big or too thick.
The default parameters are set for a typical electrical box that I purchased at Ace, so should work for most others. The magnets are 18mm Super Magnets (Neodymium) - also from Ace. I tried an earlier prototype with 8mm magnets, these didn't have sufficient power to hold the face-plate on through the sheet-rock.
There are three openings for magnets, but I've found that two are sufficient for the task. I alternated the polarity of the magnets on my version to ensure that the face plate would only orient itself in one direction. The magnets are glued in with a dab of super-glue and clamped in place until dry.
You can print multiple targets to handle multiple electrical boxes or double or triple boxes.
To use the targets: mount your electrical box and wire it. Place the target in the electrical box, flush to the surface. Install the sheet rock. Then locate the position with the face-plate. Mark the outline, cut and clear the opening.

comments.text: brilliant idea!
comments.author: Shinyhead

comments.text: This is a great jig! But one of the "no jig" trick is to take your T-square, mark the upper drywall sheet by putting the shorter part of the T-square on the floor and aligning it with the electrical box (the width of the square is the same as the one of the electrical box). Measure the bottom and the top distance from the floor of the box and note it on the upper drywall sheet. Screw the four corners of the lower drywall sheet (the sheet will bend a little over the boxes). Realign your square on the mark you've done on the upper drywall sheet, make two lines on the lower drywall sheet, take your mesurement from the floor to complete the hole marking, take your drywall saw and voilà!
comments.author: dddman

comments.text: You shouldn't be able to install the drywall until you have the holes cut because the box is supposed to sit flush with the wall when finished, not behind the drywall. ( the tabs on the box are supposed to sit against the back of the drywall )
comments.author: SayNoToMakerbot

comments.text: This is a pretty common technique - to fasten the drywall board loosely, then cut out openings (like with a rotozip), then finish screwing down the board.
comments.author: SayNoToMakerbot

comments.text: That's true. There are a couple of ways round this. You can either just loosely attach the sheet rock in place, then cut the hole and finish attaching it (depends a bit where the box is). Alternatively, you can spend a bit more on electrical boxes and get the adjustable type that move back and forth on a screw.
comments.author: SayNoToMakerbot

comments.text: Great idea! I was just getting ready to hang drywall in my workshop and was contemplating how I will find the electrical boxes. Thanks! You  have saved me a lot of work!

This is the entire rocket put together but I designed it to be modular so students can learn about how center of gravity and small design changes can affect rocket performance and functions. One would print the sections out, use a long threaded rod with nuts and washers to hold the sections together. I was inspired by the new submarine classes and NASA with modular units to outfit a smaller fleet for multiple missions thus reducing cost for missions. I have never done the tube fins before so some design modifications may be necessary. (Side bonus with 3D printing is you can adjust the density of the units to shift center mass, I thought that was a neat idea)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: I designed the sections so they could be printed without raft or supports making it cleaner, I highly advise printing in ABS and using an ABS/acetone slurry to paint over the surface to smooth out the hull.

remixed_from.author: Mikeyman64
remixed_from.title: Magazine holder for pmag 5.56 AR magazines. (2.0)

title: PMAG Magpul Magazine Holder for Stack-on safe door.

description.text: This is for the ubiquitous Stack-On 18 gun safe, Model # GCB-18-C. I liked the Pmag Magazine holder designed by Mikeyman64 (http://www.thingiverse.com/Mikeyman64/about), but I wanted to use it with my Stack-on gun safe without putting any additional holes in the safe, This mag holder mounts to the door of the safe with a simple friction fit. It seems to stay in place rather well with nothing else. Some strong double-sided tape would probably keep in place pretty permanently if you so desired. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5Q03CSQIr2t This was based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:736141 Update: I discovered that after about 18 months, the PLA I used to print these (Hatchbox) started deteriorating. The layers separated and eventually the magazine holders fell apart. This was after 18 months of holding full magazines, which is a considerable weight. I'm re-printing mine with a different PLA and different settings to try to get a better bond between the layers. I had no luck attempting to use ABS, but I think that would be a better material to use for these in the long-run. PLA is a biodegradable material and that may cause it to degrade over time.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.4mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: The door mount was too long to fit on a 200mm x 200mm print bed in one piece. Therefore, I printed it in two pieces. The joining block fits tightly in the two pieces. Most likely, you will have to file it down to get it to fit. Since full magazines are heavy, I wanted this part to be strong, resulting in the tight fit of the joining block. The original design for the holder has three holes in it for screwing to a mount of some sort. I put 1 screw through the left side to hold the send part of the mount. I did not have to use any glue to assemble this. I printed it with PLA, so I did 100% infill for maximum strength. (full magazines are heavy!). If you are using ABS, you may not have to do 100%. I am going to experiment with ABS later.

Snap together 3D printable truck-like robot. Unlike the cool-but-ultimately-non-functional Tank designs ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6554 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8080 ), this bot actually works. Sadly the motors could not generate enough torque to actually move the tank robot due to the amount of friction introduced by the worm gear and tank treads. Encouraged by the success of my 27 to 1 Reduction Gearset http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9414 I designed this bot from the ground up to be low friction, snap-together and almost entirely 3D printable. The only non-printable components are the motors, the motor mounting screws, the batteries, the wire and the nuts that serve as contacts in the battery holders. I hope to upload some PCB mounts soon so you can easily add the electronics necessary to make this bot autonomous, but if you are impatient I recommend looking into NBitWonder's awesome DC Motor Driver http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7618 which was designed for the tank-bot. I used this script to design the gears: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3575 (You will need to download the scad to use the attached truck.scad file). I also used this script to generate the battery holders: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5079 VIDEO:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F-qvDO9QZV4
As you can see from the video, the left rear axel isn't spinning freely and needs some sanding/filing. UPDATE:
I fixed the drag on the left rear axel by replacing "axelholder.stl" with "wheelholder.stl" in conjunction with "axelend2.stl".
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o3SWtk4X-1Q UPDATE #2:
I uploaded design files and instructions for the electronics:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11055
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZA7mihbLalw UPDATE #3:
Parametric oversized snaptogether 3d-printable wheels:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14347
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9cWYPE-cpFg NOTE:
This design is based on the tolerances of my cupcake 3D printer. As several folks who printed out the 27 to 1 gearset pointed out, the Thing-O-Matic has much better tolerances, so some of the snap-together parts may need some glue (or openscad tweaking) if your printer is better than mine!

In addition to the printed parts, you will need 8 AA batteries, 16 3mm hex nuts, some wire, 4 flat head machine screws (to mount the motors-- 3mm x 6mm) and two 600 RPM DC motors. I used a pair of these: http://www.batteryspace.com/dcmotorhightorquemini12vdcgearmotor600rpmforhobbyproject.aspx PRINTED PARTS: 4 x axel.stl
4 x axelend.stl
2 x axelholder.stl
2 x batteryholder3.stl
2 x batteryholder4.stl
4 x connector1.stl
1 x connector2-mirror.stl
1 x connector2.stl
2 x connector3.stl
2 x connector4.stl
1 x connector5.stl
3 x connector6.stl
2 x connector7.stl
1 x connector8.stl
4 x connector9.stl
1 x connector10.stl
2 x connector11.stl
2 x gear1.stl
2 x gear2.stl
2 x motoraxelsupport.stl
1 x motorholder-mirror.stl
1 x motorholder.stl
4 x wheel.stl
4 x wheelholder.stl UPDATE:
Replace 2 of the axelend.stl with axelend2.stl and use 2 more wheelholder.stl in place of axelholder.stl. This will significantly reduce friction on the rear (non-geared) wheels. Assemble the parts as shown in assembly.stl. Connect the batteries in series to achieve the 12 volts required by the motors. Thread wire through the battery holder holes and use pliers to snap the hex nuts into place. The hex nuts will hold the wires in place, but if you add 3mm bolts and additional nuts to the exterior of the battery holder (as suggested by obijuan in his battery holder design) that will simplify the wiring. Wire up the motors in parallel and let it rip.

This little shelf holds 20 17ml (25mm diameter) Vallejo-syle paint dropper bottles. After I saw and printed BlackBearProject's remix of this to "skeletonize" it, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2502903, I realized how badly I'd aligned the shelves, especially the bottom one. So, the OCD in me caused me to redesign this from the bottom-up as "Vallejo Dropper Paint Bottle Holder MkII" with properly aligned shelves. I'm only including the 1-piece print design here, because now that I've figured out how to do it in one piece, I have no interest in printing it in pieces ever again. That being said, feel free to mod the design on TinkerCad: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9Am4iIjC1Y0-vallejo-dropper-bottle-holder-mkii. There's an improved shelf that keeps the bottles in position better. I added a one-piece shelf where you can print it all at once. (It just now occurred to me that this was possible.) There's an optional base that you can glue to the bottom if you want to use the holder freestanding. It adds a bit more stability to the bottle holder. (Originally, this was designed to be hung on the wall, like a spice rack.) This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/h8807JxWXeV

Pills can be too large for people to swallow and many consumers have difficulty crushing these pills to make it easier for them to take. Currently available solutions often waste medication in the process of transferring the crushed medicine from a mortar to the syringe. Team Pill Crush prototyped a portable medicine grinder that also functions as a syringe using a MakerBot Replicator Desktop 3D Printer. The final device will be made of nonstick materials and include tools to round up any remaining medication. 2ndA is a modified plunger that fits inside a syringe. The plunger has two slots around the circumference for rubber seals to be placed, and a mortar-like area on the top for crushing pills inside. This design lets the user ensure no medicine is stuck to the sides of the mortar before inserting the plunger into the syringe.
2ndB is the pestle used to crush pills inside the plunger. grinder - Body1-1 is a dual pestle and plunger. One end is used to crush the pills, and the other end is used to plunge the powder (after water, etc. is added) through the syringe and into the g-tube. grinder - Body3-1 is a dual mortar and syringe. grinder - Body2-1 is a stand/mating part for the dual mortar and syringe. The syringe is placed onto the stand to create a fully sealed (at the bottom) mortar. At that point, the medicine may be crushed with the pestle. After the crushing, the medicine may be mixed with water or formula, and the syringe may then be air-sealed with the plunger. Once air-sealed, the syringe may be turned upside down and the stand may be removed to reveal the syringe opening. grinder - Body7-1 is simple rubber seal for the plunger.

For a person with limited hand control, using a spoon, fork, or knife is a significant challenge. There are feeding devices available, but they typically cost thousands of dollars and often promise more than they deliver. Using several 3D printed parts, team iEat developed a low-cost device that helps people with limited hand control to feed themselves. 
Team members: Zebreda Dunham (need knower), Clarice Torrey, Dana Yichye-Shwachamn, Ken Fujimoto, Randy Darden

description.text:
Created an action camera mount for my Sony action cam. Things you need to purchase:
1) One: 3/4" PVC SCH-40 pipe. Mine had a 1.055" OD and 0.80" ID
2) Four: 1/4-20 x 2.5" hex bolts
3) Four: 1/4-20 nuts
4) Swivel camera head. Mine happen to come with M4 thread to mount so i bought a M4x20 hex bolt to thread it on. The "Flat Bracket" and the "Inside Washer" need holes drilled in them afterwards for the threaded portion of the screw. Didn't have a good way to get those holes in there without supports. Most of the STL's will probably have to be flipped around before printing. Just use your wisdom for orientation :P Bolts and nuts press fit into the parts. Oh, and the posts for my headrest measured 14mm in diameter. Other than that, just drill holes where necessary, mount, and go! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y16krU1lUCQ **Update: created another way to hold a Sony Action Cam
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1320725

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 and .3mm

50%

This is a simple customizable box with lid.
The box can be made of any size, and its section can be any regular polygon (triangle, square, pentagon, hexagon, and so on...). You can choose wall thickness and the clearance between the box and the lid, as well as width and height of both box and lid. You can also choose to just print the box, or the lid, or both.
It's a useful Thing if you need a box for something in particular and just can't find the right size. Just put in the right measurements and print it out!
Customization of this model is pretty straightforward, all parameters are explained in-line.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

30%

Notes: This is a very easy model to print, nothing particular about it, walls are all vertical.
Perhaps the only risk is a bit of warping if you make it very large. If you use an Outer Radius of 30mm or above, I suggest using a raft or some other anti-warp mechanism (I use stick glue on my glass plate), to be on the safe side. Also, the value of the Clearance between the lid and the box should be set according to your printer's level of precision, to avoid having a lid that doesn't fit in the box, or that is too loose.

comments.text:
Hi Alex
Made 40 boxes so far for family and friends, from 4 sides to 9 sides, with and without lids, largest ones 80x80x60mm. Also I am able to change colour with my printer during printing ie on the fly. The 5 colour changes on the 4 sided box (orange, black, white, black, orange) and (pink, black, white, black, pink) They look like a UK sweet called Licorice Allsorts.
Really good to be able to change parameters with Customiser, thank you for the addition to be able to change the lid lip depth.
Best regards - John
comments.author: johnrod

comments.text: Hi Alex Thank you very much, I am new to 3D printing, Thingiverse, Cura and no CAD experience. Just love printing. Regards John
comments.author: johnrod

comments.text:
Hi I have now made 10 boxes of different shapes and sizes, these are for a friend of mine who made jewellery for her family and friends The boxes make lovely presentations for her jewellery. I have used 0.3 for the lid clearance but is there any way I can make lid lip any deeper, say 3 or 4mm, this would make it more secure, or is this something you would have to change?
Kind regards John
comments.author: johnrod

comments.text:
Hi John, I'm very happy to know which use you put my boxes to!
I just made an update on the design, you now have an additional parameter (Lid Lip Depth) to modify and you can freely decide how many millimeters the lip should sink into the box.
Unfortunately, I believe you will have to re-customize the design to make the boxes again, to be able to modify the lip depth...
Hope this helps!
